required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy of Personal Pharmacogenomic Testing as an Educational Tool in the Pharmacy Curriculum
clinical_study.official_title: Efficacy of Personal Pharmacogenomic Testing as an Educational Tool in the Pharmacy Curriculum

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to evaluate the use of personal genomic educational testing (PGET) on student knowledge and clinical skills surrounding pharmacogenomic testing to ensure it is of educational benefit to our student population. Students will be provided the opportunity to opt-in to test their own pharmacogenomic panel while participating in the standard curriculum. Students will have the option of using their own reports or dummy reports during classroom activities. Our hypothesis is that those students who have their own pharmacogenomics tested will show better overall performance.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: We investigated the effect of PGET on student knowledge, comfort, and attitudes related to pharmacogenomics (PGx) in a non-blinded, randomized controlled trial. Consenting participants were randomized to receive PGET or no PGET (NPGET) during four subsequent years of a PGx course.
study_design_info.masking_description: Instructors and all study personnel were blinded to participant PGET assignment, PGx results, and survey results.

primary_outcome.description: Improvement in performance on a knowledge assessment including eleven questions

secondary_outcome.description: Improvement in Likert Scale Responses for 27 questions (scale of 1[worst] to 6[best])

arm_group.description: PGET group participants received their own pharmacogenomic testing results prior to the course modules covering material tested in the knowledge assessment
No PGET (NPGET) group participants did not receive their own pharmacogenomic testing results until after study completion.

intervention.description: PGET consisted of a panel of pharmacogenomic variants

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Willingness to provide informed consent for participation in the study
- Enrolled in 3rd year Doctor of Pharmacy course
Exclusion Criteria:
- Unwilling or unable to provide consent for participation
